question_details.title: Will the US military's climate resiliance portal be back online on April 1, 2025?
question_details.description: The Guardian [Scientists brace ‘for the worst’ as Trump purges climate mentions from websites](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/feb/04/trump-climate-change-federal-websites)
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if climate.mil is online according to [Is It Down Right Now?](https://www.isitdownrightnow.com/climate.mil.html) when accessed by Metaculus on or after April 1, 2025.
question_details.fine_print: As of February 26, 2025, the resolution source returns the mesasge, "Climate.mil is DOWN for everyone."

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Ministry of Environment, Urbanization and Climate Change to Hire 78 Expert Assistants**
The Ministry of Environment, Urbanization and Climate Change will be hiring 78 expert assistants. Applicants can submit their applications through the e-Devlet portal, specifically through the 'Kariyer Kapısı' (Career Gate) on the website https://isealimkariyerkapisi.cbiko.gov.tr. The application period will start on March 5, 2025, and end on March 16, 2025, at 23:59:59. To be eligible, applicants must have a bachelor's degree from a university with a minimum four-year program in one of the following fields, or have a degree from an equivalent institution recognized by the Higher Education Council.
Original language: tr
Publish date: March 06, 2025 07:14 AM
Source:[HABERTURK.COM](https://m.haberturk.com/cevre-sehircilik-ve-iklim-degisikligi-bakanligi-78-uzman-yardimcisi-alacak-basvuru-sartlari-nelerdir-3771360)

**US Halts Global Air Quality Data Program Due to Budget Constraints**
The US authorities have stopped a program that provides global air quality data through sensors at over 80 embassies and consulates due to budget constraints. This move comes as the Trump administration is imposing restrictions on funding for environmental and climate work abroad. According to a statement from the State Department, as of Tuesday, live data is no longer being transmitted through diplomatic websites for posting on an electronic portal and a mobile app. The statement said, 'Our current climate budget requires us to make difficult cuts, unfortunately, we cannot continue to publish these data.' 
Original language: ar
Publish date: March 05, 2025 09:06 PM
Source:[البيان](https://www.albayan.ae/economy/future/sustainability/31518)

**Ukraine Introduces Electronic Decisions for Military Medical Commissions**
The Ukrainian Ministry of Defense has introduced online submissions for military medical commission (VLC) decisions. Starting from April 2025, digital decisions will be mandatory for all VLCs. According to Minister of Defense Rustem Umeyev, 'paper decisions are a thing of the past. Now they will be submitted online: quickly, simply, without bureaucracy.' The electronic decisions will be stored in the Medical Information System (MIS) of the Armed Forces. From March 1, 2025, VLCs that have completed the necessary training will be able to submit electronic decisions, while from April, all commissions will be required to do so.
Original language: uk
Publish date: March 05, 2025 04:41 PM
Source:[Украинская правда](https://life.pravda.com.ua/society/v-ukrajini-zaprovadili-elektronni-visnovki-vlk-detali-306782/)

**Ukraine to Implement Online Decision-Making for Military-Medical Commissions**
Ukraine continues to reform its military-medical commissions to simplify the process for military personnel. Starting from March 1, 2025, trained military-medical commissions will be able to issue electronic decisions, and from April 1, this will be mandatory for all commissions. 'Paper conclusions are a thing of the past. Now they will be issued online: quickly, simply, without bureaucracy,' said Umerov.
Original language: uk
Publish date: March 05, 2025 02:56 PM
Source:[РБК-Украина](https://www.rbc.ua/rus/news/ukrayini-vidsogodni-postanovi-vlk-budut-oformlyuvati-1741184290.html)

**Ukraine to Implement Online Verdicts for Military Medical Commissions**
According to a Facebook post by Defense Minister Rustom Umerov, Ukraine will begin reforming its military medical commissions to simplify processes for military personnel. Starting March 1, 2025, trained military medical commissions will be able to issue electronic verdicts, and starting April 1, this will be mandatory for all commissions. As Umerov said, 'Paper conclusions are a thing of the past. Now they will be issued online: quickly, simply, without bureaucracy.' 
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 05, 2025 02:53 PM
Source:[РБК-Украина](https://www.rbc.ua/ukr/news/ukrayini-vidsogodni-postanovi-vlk-budut-oformlyuvati-1741184290.html)

**Reform of VLC: Electronic Accounting Becomes Mandatory from April 1**
The Ministry of Defense of Ukraine has launched an electronic cabinet for the military-medical commission (VLC) in the Medical Information System of the Armed Forces of Ukraine. According to Minister of Defense Rustem Umeyev, the digital format will simplify and speed up the process of document preparation. 'We continue to reform the military-medical commissions to make their work more convenient and transparent for every Ukrainian. Paper conclusions are in the past - from now on, they will be issued online: quickly, simply, without unnecessary bureaucracy,' said Umeyev. The data on referrals to VLC will be sent directly to the electronic cabinet from the Obereg register. The decisions of the commissions after medical examinations of conscripts will automatically be recorded in the Obereg register and will be displayed in the Reserv+ application. All information about the decisions of military personnel will be recorded in the Medical Information System of the Armed Forces of Ukraine. According to Umeyev, the digitalization of VLC has already started. From March 1, 2025, commissions that have undergone relevant training will be able to issue electronic decisions, and from April 1, 2025, the electronic format will become mandatory for all VLC. 'Earlier, all documents were filled in manually. Now we are moving to digital technologies, which will allow us to minimize bureaucracy and increase the efficiency of the work of the commissions,' concluded Umeyev.
Original language: uk
Publish date: March 05, 2025 02:44 PM
Source:[Gazeta.ua](https://gazeta.ua/articles/life/_reforma-vlk-z-1-kvitnya-elektronnij-oblik-stane-obovyazkovim/1210434)

**Electronic Cabinet of VCLK: How the New Service Will Work**
Starting from March 1, 2025, electronic verdicts can be issued by military-medical commissions that have undergone training, and from April 1, this will be mandatory for all VCLK. According to Defense Minister Rustem Umerov, the online issuance of conclusions will be fast, simple, and without bureaucracy. Umerov emphasized, 'We will continue to reform military-medical commissions to make the processes convenient and understandable for every Ukrainian.' The minister also explained how the electronic cabinet of VCLK works. The project was the result of joint work between the Ministry of Defense, the Ministry of Health, the General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine, and the BRDO Office for Effective Regulation. It is worth noting that during mobilization in Ukraine, VCLK determines the suitability for military service. However, the commission's decision can be canceled for various reasons, including formal errors, investigations into commission members, or changes in legislation.
Original language: uk
Publish date: March 05, 2025 02:08 PM
Source:[24 Канал](https://24tv.ua/elektronniy-kabinet-vlk-minoboroni-rozpovili-yak-pratsyuvatime_n2768330)

**Electronic Cabinet of VVK: How the New Service Will Work**
Starting from March 1, 2025, electronic verdicts can be issued by military-medical commissions that have undergone training, and from April 1, this will be mandatory for all VVK. According to Defense Minister Rustem Umerov, the online verdicts will be issued quickly, simply, and without bureaucracy. Umerov emphasized, 'We continue to reform military-medical commissions to make the processes convenient and understandable for every Ukrainian.' The minister also explained how the electronic cabinet of VVK works. This project is the result of joint work between the Ministry of Defense, the Ministry of Health, the General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine, and the BRDO Office for Efficient Regulation. It's worth noting that during mobilization in Ukraine, VVK determines the suitability for military service. However, the commission's decision can be overturned for various reasons, including formal errors, investigations against commission members, or changes in legislation.
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 05, 2025 02:06 PM
Source:[24 Канал](https://24tv.ua/ru/jelektronnyj-kabinet-vvk-minoborony-rasskazali-budet-rabotat_n2768342)

**Ukraine's Military Medical Commission Goes Online**
From today, decisions of the Military Medical Commission (VLC) will be made online. Medical conclusions will be automatically sent to the 'Oboroh' registry and displayed in the 'Reserv+' app. According to Minister of Defense Rustem Umeyrov, 'Paper conclusions are a thing of the past. Now they will be made online: quickly, simply, without bureaucracy.' He added that referrals to the commission will automatically be sent from the 'Oboroh' registry to the VLC cabinet. Medical conclusions after inspections of conscripts will automatically be sent to 'Oboroh' and displayed in 'Reserv+' faster. Decisions regarding servicemen will be stored in the Military Medical Information System of the ZSU. Umeyrov reminded that since March 1, 2025, military medical commissions that have undergone training can make electronic decisions. Starting April 1, this will be mandatory for all VLCs.
Original language: uk
Publish date: March 05, 2025 02:03 PM
Source:[ТСН.ua](https://tsn.ua/ukrayina/vidsogodni-postanovi-vlk-oformlyuvatimut-onlayn-podrobici-2780904.html)

**Ukrainian Military Medical Commissions to Issue Online Decisions**
Ukrainian Defense Minister Rostyslav Umerov announced that military medical commissions will now issue online decisions, eliminating the need for paper-based conclusions. According to Umerov, 'Paper-based conclusions are a thing of the past. Now they will be issued online: quickly, simply, and without bureaucracy.' The system will automatically send referrals to the commissions from the 'Oboroh' registry and display the results in the 'Reserv+' app. The decisions will be stored in the Medical Information System of the Ukrainian Armed Forces. Umerov noted that since March 1, electronic decisions can be issued by military medical commissions that have completed training, and from April 1, this will be mandatory for all commissions.
Original language: uk
Publish date: March 05, 2025 01:44 PM
Source:[УКРІНФОРМ](https://www.ukrinform.ua/rubric-society/3967179-postanovi-vlk-vidsogodni-oformluvatimut-onlajn-umerov.html)

**Among the Trump Administration's first Pentagon cuts: Programs that respond to climate change**
The US military is set to cut its budget by 8% over the next five years, with climate change programs being an early target. However, national security experts argue that the Pentagon's climate change efforts are actually focused on warfare and not purely environmental purposes. Tom Ellison of the Center for Climate and Security notes that climate change will impact the military's ability to operate, including extreme heat and pollution affecting troop health, changes in ocean chemistry affecting submarine sonar, and changes in humidity affecting aircraft lift capacity. The military is also building resilience into its infrastructure planning, with some installations expected to be abandoned due to rising sea levels. Despite bipartisan support for the military's climate change efforts, the Defense Department has taken down its official climate resilience portal and has not responded to questions about which climate-related programs will be eliminated.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 10:06 AM
Source:[whro.org](https://www.whro.org/military-veterans/2025-02-26/among-the-trump-administrations-first-pentagon-cuts-programs-that-respond-to-climate-change)

**Ukrainian Government Extends Deadline for Military Reservists**
The Ukrainian government has extended the deadline for military reservists to postpone their conscription until the end of March. According to Taras Melnychuk, the government's representative in the parliament, the Cabinet of Ministers has made changes to the resolution of the CMU #1332 of November 22, 2023, 'Some issues related to the booking of military reservists during mobilization and wartime'. Melnychuk wrote, 'It has been established that the postponements of conscription during mobilization, which were granted to military reservists by decisions of the Ministry of Economy or through the 'Diia' portal and whose validity period has not expired on the day of the adoption of these changes, are valid until March 31, 2025.' The government has also made changes to the resolution of the CMU #36 of January 14, allowing companies to re-book their employees through the 'Diia' portal without a 72-hour verification period until April 1. As Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal said, 'Companies will have time to confirm their status as critical and to re-book their personnel. Due to the large-scale Russian cyberattack on our registers, some time was lost, and we are giving them the opportunity to make up for it.'
Original language: uk
Publish date: February 25, 2025 04:35 PM
Source:[gordonua.com](https://gordonua.com/ukr/news/politics/kabmin-ukrajini-prodovzhiv-diju-vidstrochok-zabronovanikh-vijskovozobovjazanikh-pratsivnikiv-1734682.html)

**EPA unfreezes some climate grants**
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has unfrozen its climate grants, with the exception of the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund, which is still frozen. Awardees of other EPA grant programs under the 2022 climate law reported being able to access the federal government's portal to receive funds, after being frozen since January 28. The EPA had stated that the pause was for a 'review' of the programs. Notably, two of the three programs under the $27 billion GGRF were untouched by the freeze, as the funds were held in accounts at Citibank with the recipients' names on them.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 20, 2025 09:42 PM
Source:[E&E News](https://www.eenews.net/articles/epa-unfreezes-some-climate-grants/)

**Military Health System Beneficiaries Urged to Download Old Medical Records by April 1**
The Department of Defense is urging military health system beneficiaries to download their old medical records by April 1, as the Tricare Online Patient Portal will be decommissioned. Rear Adm. Tracy Farrill, a DHA electronic health records expert, said, 'All military hospitals and clinics have transitioned to MHS Genesis. We encourage you to take these important steps to save your personal health records before the [Tricare Online] Patient Portal decommissions.' Patients can download their records by signing in to www.tricareonline.com and following the instructions. However, legacy records may not be complete, and new MHS Genesis records do not contain information from previous electronic and paper health records. Providers still have access to those records to treat patients. The Defense Department has transitioned to MHS Genesis, which is now used at 138 military hospitals and clinics and more than 3,600 DoD locations worldwide.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 10:40 PM
Source:[Military](https://www.military.com/daily-news/2025/02/18/military-health-system-beneficiaries-urged-download-old-medical-records-april-1.html)

**Sec. Hegseth: DOD Climate Programs Ripe For Cuts, Military Should Focus On War-Fighting**
Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth has suggested cutting Department of Defense (DOD) climate change programs to reduce spending, stating, 'The Defense Department is not in the business of climate change, solving the global thermostat. We’re in the business of deterring and winning wars.' Hegseth believes the Biden administration 'underinvested' in the military, but wants to increase the defense budget. However, the Biden administration has framed climate change as a military priority, with efforts including net-zero installations and leveraging renewable energy technologies. The 2024-2027 Climate Adaptation Plan outlines the military's mitigation goals, including enhancing resilience through renewable energy and microgrids. The proposed defense budget for 2023 included $3.7 billion for 'installation resiliency and adaptation' and $1.5 billion for research and development, operational energy, and contingency preparedness.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 17, 2025 06:47 PM
Source:[climatechangedispatch.com](https://climatechangedispatch.com/sec-hegseth-dod-climate-programs-ripe-for-cuts-military-should-focus-on-war-fighting/)

**Brazil Establishes National Day for Climate Action**
The Brazilian Chamber of Deputies has approved a bill that establishes April 27th as the National Day for Climate Action. The bill, proposed by Deputy Duda Salabert, aims to promote climate action and disaster preparedness among schools. According to Salabert, the date was chosen because it marks the beginning of the heavy rains in Rio Grande do Sul in 2024. 'The proposal is also a way to remember the lives lost due to human inaction regarding climate change across the country,' she said. The bill requires schools to develop activities focused on prevention, reduction, protection, and response to extreme weather events and natural disasters. These activities will include training, exercises, and practical actions such as creating emergency evacuation routes, conducting environmental education, and preparing emergency kits.
Original language: pt
Publish date: February 12, 2025 11:15 PM
Source:[Portal da Câmara dos Deputados](https://www.camara.leg.br/noticias/1133050-camara-aprova-projeto-que-cria-o-dia-nacional-para-a-acao-climatica/)

**First Up: Modi in Paris for AI Summit, Aero India 2025 in Bengaluru... The headlines today**
Today's headlines cover global diplomacy, defense, legal battles, and environmental commitments. Prime Minister Narendra Modi co-chairs the AI Action Summit in Paris with French President Emmanuel Macron, focusing on ethical AI governance. Meanwhile, Aero India 2025 kicks off in Bengaluru, showcasing cutting-edge aerospace technology. In the UK, farmers protest outside Parliament over agricultural policies, while key legal hearings unfold in India, including a case against Sonia Gandhi and petitions on Rohingya settlements. The deadline for countries to submit updated climate action plans under the Paris Agreement arrives, marking a crucial moment in global environmental policy. As Macron said, 'This significant event aims to establish global standards for ethical and sustainable AI development.' Notable attendees include US Vice President JD Vance, China's Vice Premier Ding Xuexiang, and leaders from major tech companies like Alphabet and Microsoft. The summit will address issues such as labour disruption, environmental sustainability, and the equitable distribution of AI benefits. The 15th edition of Aero India, Asia's premier aerospace and defence exhibition, begins today at Yelahanka Air Force Station in Bengaluru, running from February 10 to 14, 2025. The event showcases advanced military and civil aviation technology, featuring aerial displays, exhibitions, and seminars. Industry leaders, defence experts, and aviation enthusiasts from around the globe are in attendance. The exhibition provides a platform for collaboration and business opportunities in the aerospace sector, highlighting India's growing capabilities in defence production and aviation technology. In London, farmers have organised a tractor protest outside the UK Parliament, voicing concerns over agricultural policies and their impact on the farming community. The demonstration aims to draw attention to issues such as fair pricing, subsidies, and environmental regulations affecting the agricultural sector. The Supreme Court of India is set to hear a batch of pleas challenging the Calcutta High Court's April 22 decision regarding irregularities in school recruitment processes in West Bengal. The petitions question the legality of the recruitment procedures and seek redressal for affected candidates. Today marks the deadline for countries to submit their updated national climate action plans, known as Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), under the Paris Agreement. These plans outline each country's efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to the impacts of climate change, contributing to global climate goals. As the article states, 'The timely submission of NDCs is crucial for assessing global progress in combating climate change and ensuring that collective efforts are aligned with the targets set in the Paris Agreement.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 10, 2025 01:58 AM
Source:[Firstpost](https://www.firstpost.com/explainers/first-up-modi-in-paris-for-ai-summit-aero-india-2025-in-bengaluru-the-headlines-today-13861126.html)

**Trump and Project 2025: President's early moves mirror conservative playbook - National | Globalnews.ca**
Donald Trump's early executive orders in his second term align with many ideas promoted in Project 2025, a conservative policy agenda published by the Heritage Foundation in April 2023. Over 30 of Trump's 47 early executive orders show clear parallels with Project 2025, including ending certain international agreements, loosening environmental regulations, and scaling back on or dismantling diversity, equity and inclusion programs. Trump has repeatedly denied any involvement with Project 2025, but experts say it's likely that his team has searched for recommendations that align with his policies. Project 2025 proposed a freeze on 'all top career-position hiring' to 'prevent 'burrowing in' by outgoing political appointees,' which Trump's White House has ordered. The blueprint also recommended that Health and Human Services cancel programs that recognize transgender people and that the government withdraw all guidance to teens seeking 'gender-affirming care' or 'gender transition.' Trump has taken steps to implement these recommendations, including ending federal funding for gender-affirming care for minors and rescinding protections for transgender Americans to serve in the military. Project 2025 proposed ending programs designed to meet the Paris climate agreement, with the goal of ceasing a 'global, climate-themed agenda' and the 'perceived threat of climate change.' Trump's White House has started the process of withdrawing from the Paris climate agreement, including financial commitments and related agreements. 'Trump is, if nothing else, predictable. He'll do what makes him look like a winner and implementing the sweeping programs in Project 2025 is an easy pathway to looking like a winner,' said Aaron Ettinger, Associate Professor in the Department of Political Science at Carleton University.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 31, 2025 06:22 PM
Source:[Global News](https://globalnews.ca/news/10989366/donald-trump-project-2025-executive-orders-comparison/)

**Medicaid portal freeze sparks nationwide confusion with users in all 50 states locked out of accounts**
The Medicaid benefits portal went dark nationwide, leaving recipients confused and without access to their accounts. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt assured that no payments have been affected and that the portal will be back online shortly. Leavitt defended President Trump's plan to audit spending and cut progressive programs, saying the administration wants to be 'good stewards' of taxpayer money. Trump has also promised to release classified documents related to the assassinations of President John F Kennedy, Senator Robert Kennedy, and Civil Rights leader Martin Luther King. Additionally, he has vowed to reinstate a ban on transgender military service and ban transgender women from competing in women's sports. Trump has also promised to overturn President Biden's climate policies and visit Los Angeles in the wake of recent devastating wildfires.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 28, 2025 07:45 PM
Source:[the-sun.com](https://www.the-sun.com/news/13401667/medicaid-down-portal-freeze-donald-trump-spending-cut/)

**Putin Signs Decree on Call-up of Citizens in Reserve for Military Training in 2025**
Russian President Vladimir Putin has signed a decree to call up citizens in reserve for military training in 2025. According to the decree, published on the official portal of legal information, citizens in reserve will be called up for military training in the Armed Forces, National Guard, rescue units, state security, and federal security. The decree comes into effect on the day of publication. The government and regional authorities are tasked with ensuring the implementation of all measures related to the conduct of these training sessions. The training is aimed at improving combat readiness and is a planned annual event. Reservists can receive summons every three years in both paper and electronic form. The maximum duration of training is two months. Typically, the call-up of those in reserve occurs once a year. In 2023, Putin signed a decree on the call-up for military training on May 10, and in 2024, on March 1. As a reminder, the Russian Ministry of Defense also announced the end of the autumn conscription for military service on December 28. A total of 133,000 people were called up for military service, with the dispatch of conscripts from collection points beginning on October 15. The next, spring, conscription campaign will begin on April 1 and end on July 15. It is worth noting that significant amendments to the law 'On Military Obligation and Military Service' were adopted in the spring of 2023. At the same time, it was reported that the accounting of military personnel would be carried out automatically, and summons would be sent through 'Gosuslugi.' In December 2024, Putin instructed the Ministry of Defense to conduct the autumn conscription using the electronic register of military personnel and the register of summons. Head of the Defense Committee of the State Duma Andrei Kartapolov said that the previous autumn conscription was based on paper summons. According to him, electronic summons are currently being tested in three regions - the Riazan region, Mari El, and Sakhalin.
Original language: ru
Publish date: January 16, 2025 05:57 PM
Source:[БИЗНЕС Online — Новости Казани, Татарстана, общество, политика, рейтинги, эксперты](https://www.business-gazeta.ru/news/660140)

**Overseas military pharmacies are moving to interactive phone-in refills**
U.S. military pharmacies overseas are transitioning to an interactive, voice-response system for prescription refills, with the goal of completing the transition by June 2025. According to DHA spokesman Peter Graves, the new system is about 78% complete, with most military treatment facilities having already updated their pharmacy labels and websites with their new phone number. Patients can still refill prescriptions using the MHS Genesis Patient Portal online, and the transition will not affect existing prescriptions or refills. Some patients are hopeful that the new system will be an improvement, as it may be easier to use than the previous online system. As Graves said, 'The digital refill call system is already active, and we are working towards new capabilities that are being piloted by Edwards [Air Force Base], to include refill pickup notifications.'
Original language: en
Publish date: January 16, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[stripes.com](https://www.stripes.com/theaters/asia_pacific/2025-01-16/prescription-refills-military-pharmacies-16499011.html)

**Government's 'Clean Air' Program to Resume in 2025 with Reforms**
The government's 'Clean Air' program will be reinstated on April 1, 2025, according to Minister of Climate and Environment Paulina Hennig-Kloska. She stated that after consulting with the National Fund for Environmental Protection and Water Management, she set a deadline for the program's return. Changes will be made, focusing on the way controls and subsidies are administered. The National Fund for Environmental Protection and Water Management suspended new applications to the program in late November, citing the need for reform and system tightening. In December, the Fund reported that it had filed a complaint with the prosecutor's office regarding several companies suspected of committing crimes under the program, with disputed contracts totaling approximately 600 million zł.
Original language: pl
Publish date: January 10, 2025 10:19 AM
Source:[www.money.pl](https://www.money.pl/gospodarka/oto-termin-powrotu-rzadowego-programu-beda-kontrole-wkroczy-skarbowka-7112709778238176a.html)

**2025 Bedelli Askerlik Yerleri Ne Zaman Açıklanacak?**
Following the announcement by the Turkish Ministry of National Defense that applications for voluntary military service would begin on January 7, 2025, attention has turned to the online portal for inquiring about the locations for this service. According to a statement from the General Directorate of Recruitment, individuals whose two-month payment period ends after December 31, 2024 at 18:00 will make their payments at the new rate. Those who applied in 2024 are now waiting to find out their assigned locations for 2025. Successful applicants can check their assigned locations through the E-Devlet portal. The question remains: when will the locations for voluntary military service be announced in 2025? Have the locations been announced or revealed? Here is the information on the recruitment periods and E-Devlet inquiry portal.
Original language: tr
Publish date: January 08, 2025 04:24 PM
Source:[Hürriyet](https://www.hurriyet.com.tr/arama/bedelli-askerlik-yerleri-2025)

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, government websites that go offline due to political decisions, especially associated with controversial issues like climate change, have a mixed record of being restored promptly. Given the past actions where policy-driven changes can lead sites to stay down for extended periods, I estimate a reasonable initial probability that the portal will be back online by the specified date. Assuming similar past events, such as the 2017 EPA website adjustments, indicating about 30% probability for an early restoration within a couple of months.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Automation and AI in Web Management
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Advancements in automation and AI can significantly speed up the process of restoring websites due to improved deployment and management systems. These technologies allow for efficient diagnostic and repair processes, potentially increasing the chance of the site being restored on time.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Political Climate
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Given the fluctuating nature of political control over issues such as climate change, there is inherent uncertainty. The political climate, particularly surrounding environmental issues, often dictates the speed with which services like the climate resilience portal might be restored.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Technical Resources Allocation
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Assuming there is prioritization in the allocation of technical resources towards more critical projects due to budget constraints or strategic decisions, this factor might reduce the likelihood of a swift restoration.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The US military is actively cutting budgets for climate-related programs, as shown in the news articles mentioning the cessation of global air quality data due to budget constraints and statements by Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth indicating cuts in climate programs to refocus on war-fighting.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: No new information directly contradicts the assessment that the climate resiliency portal is unlikely to return given the political climate and budgetary reallocations.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: To estimate the probability of the US military's climate resilience portal being back online by April 1, 2025, we consider the historical frequency of government-related websites being taken offline and restored. Typically, websites are taken down for maintenance, technical difficulties, or policy changes, and historically, essential government websites, particularly those related to national security and operational strategy (such as military sites), are prioritized for reinstatement. The historical base rate for government websites being restored after going offline is relatively high, estimated at around 70%, since government operations prioritize functionality and access to critical information.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Political Climate and Policy Changes
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The political leadership in place may deprioritize certain climate-related initiatives, especially if there has been a recent change indicating a strategic pivot away from climate-related transparency. Given historical context, such as previous administrative decisions, this factor could reduce the likelihood of the portal being reinstated.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Technical and Operational Prioritization
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Military and defense operations typically prioritize uptime for strategic operations and resilience information. Technical teams likely have existing protocols to resolve outages effectively. This operational efficiency increases the likelihood of the portal being back online.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Scrutiny and Public Accountability Pressure
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Public pressure, especially from entities concerned with national security and environmental issues, could lead to a swifter resolution due to increased scrutiny and demand. This factor tends to increase compliance and restoration efforts.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news article titled 'Military Health System Beneficiaries Urged to Download Old Medical Records by April 1' indicates that the Department of Defense is aware of impending deadlines related to online systems and is taking steps to communicate with users to ensure compliance. summary: After evaluating new information related to the US military's climate resilience portal, experts revised their predictions on whether the portal will be back online by April 1, 2025. Overall, the majority of experts decreased their probability estimates, citing ongoing political and budgetary constraints under the Trump administration that deprioritize climate-related initiatives. Initial probabilities ranged from 30% to 80%, with most experts adjusting downward by 5% to 20% after phase 2 analysis, resulting in revised probabilities between 20% and 70%. Common factors influencing these adjustments included reinforced evidence of budget cuts to climate programs and lack of direct actions towards restoring the portal. Conversely, a few experts considered potential public and international pressure or technical ease of restoration, but these factors were generally outweighed by the prevailing negative political climate.
